metadata.title: Database of Untranslated Ancient & Medieval Texts
metadata.description: Comprehensive catalog of digitized manuscripts awaiting English translation

sanskrit.name: Sanskrit Logic, Philosophy & Grammar
sanskrit.description: India produced 30+ million manuscripts - 100x more than Greek and Latin combined. The Nyāya-Navya-Nyāya tradition developed sophisticated logic systems centuries before Frege.

texts.author: Bhartṛhari
texts.title: Vākyapadīya
texts.significance: Sphoṭa theory of meaning - language philosophy predating Saussure by 1400 years. Book III (Prakīrṇaka) remains largely untranslated.

texts.author: Raghunātha Śiromaṇi
texts.title: Padārthatattvanirūpaṇa
texts.significance: Revolutionary treatise introducing new logical categories. Transformed Indian logic comparable to Frege's impact on Western logic.

texts.author: Raghunātha Śiromaṇi
texts.title: Dīdhiti (on Tattvacintāmaṇi)
texts.significance: The foundational Navya-Nyāya commentary that all later commentators respond to. Created the technical vocabulary still used today.

texts.author: Jagadīśa Tarkālaṅkāra
texts.title: Śabdaśaktiprakāśikā
texts.significance: Definitive work on the philosophy of language in Navya-Nyāya. Analyzes how words convey meaning with unprecedented precision.

texts.author: Gadādhara Bhaṭṭācārya
texts.title: Vyutpattivāda
texts.significance: How do we learn language? Gadādhara's answer anticipates debates in modern linguistics about innateness and acquisition.

texts.author: Gadādhara Bhaṭṭācārya
texts.title: Śaktivāda
texts.significance: On word-meaning relations. The culmination of Navya-Nyāya philosophy of language.

texts.author: Mathurānātha Tarkavāgīśa
texts.title: Mathurī (commentary on Tattvacintāmaṇi)
texts.significance: The rival Navya-Nyāya school's response to Raghunātha. Essential for understanding the debates.

texts.author: Vāsudeva Sārvabhauma
texts.title: Tattvacintāmaṇivyākhyā
texts.significance: The first great work of the Navadvipa school. Established Bengal as the center of Navya-Nyāya learning.

texts.author: Annaṁbhatta
texts.title: Tarkasaṁgraha with Dīpikā
texts.significance: Popular manual combining ancient and new schools. Still taught today - gateway to Indian logic.
texts.existingTranslations: Some translations exist but need modern scholarly editions

texts.author: Viśvanātha Nyāyapañcānana
texts.title: Nyāyasūtravṛtti
texts.significance: Important late commentary on the Nyāya Sūtras incorporating Navya-Nyāya developments.

texts.author: Appaya Dīkṣita
texts.title: Śivārkamaṇidīpikā
texts.significance: Suggests level of logical studies in South India may have been far superior to usually accepted.

texts.author: Gadādhara Bhaṭṭācārya
texts.title: Bauddha Adhāra Vivṛtti
texts.significance: Refutation of Buddhist logic using Navya-Nyāya methods. Key text for inter-school debates.

texts.author: Dharmakīrti
texts.title: Nyāyabindu
texts.significance: Concise manual of Buddhist epistemology. Highly influential across Tibet, China, and Japan.

texts.author: Dharmottara
texts.title: Nyāyabinduṭīkā
texts.significance: Standard commentary on Nyāyabindu. Essential for understanding Dharmakīrti.

texts.author: Prajñākaragupta
texts.title: Pramāṇavārttikālaṅkāra
texts.significance: Major commentary on Dharmakīrti's masterwork. Contains independent philosophical arguments.

texts.author: Jayanta Bhaṭṭa
texts.title: Nyāyamañjarī
texts.significance: Encyclopedic work defending Nyāya against Buddhist and Mīmāṃsā critiques. Philosophically rich debates.
texts.existingTranslations: Only portions translated; full work unavailable

texts.author: Kumārila Bhaṭṭa
texts.title: Ślokavārttika
texts.significance: Defense of Vedic authority with sophisticated epistemology. Major influence on later Indian philosophy.

texts.author: Prabhākara
texts.title: Bṛhatī
texts.significance: Rival Mīmāṃsā interpretation to Kumārila. Different theory of meaning and knowledge.

texts.author: Śālikanātha
texts.title: Prakaraṇapañcikā
texts.significance: Systematic exposition of Prābhākara Mīmāṃsā. Key for understanding alternative Indian epistemology.

texts.author: Vācaspati Miśra
texts.title: Nyāyavārttikatātparyaṭīkā
texts.significance: Comprehensive commentary establishing orthodox Nyāya interpretation. Influenced all later Nyāya.

texts.author: Udayana
texts.title: Ātmatattvaviveka
texts.significance: Definitive Nyāya defense of the existence of the self against Buddhist no-self doctrine.

texts.author: Udayana
texts.title: Nyāyakusumāñjali
texts.significance: Five proofs for God's existence - sophisticated natural theology. Bridge between old and new Nyāya.

texts.author: Patañjali
texts.title: Mahābhāṣya
texts.significance: The Great Commentary on Pāṇini. Foundational for Sanskrit linguistics and philosophy of language.
texts.existingTranslations: Kielhorn edition exists; no complete English translation

texts.author: Helārāja
texts.title: Prakīrṇaprakāśa (on Vākyapadīya III)
texts.significance: Major commentary on Bhartṛhari's philosophy of language. Essential for understanding sphoṭa theory.

texts.author: Maṇḍana Miśra
texts.title: Sphoṭasiddhi
texts.significance: Defense of sphoṭa theory of meaning. Links grammar philosophy to Advaita Vedānta.

arabic.name: Arabic Logic, Automata & Algorithms
arabic.description: The Islamic Golden Age (750-1258 CE) preserved Greek philosophy while developing original contributions in logic, mathematics, and mechanics that directly shaped modern computing and science.

texts.author: al-Khwārizmī
texts.title: Kitāb al-Jabr wa'l-Muqābala
texts.significance: Gave us ALGEBRA and ALGORITHM. The book that named two fundamental concepts in computing.

texts.author: al-Jazarī
texts.title: Kitāb fī Ma'rifat al-Ḥiyal al-Handasiyya
texts.significance: Book of Ingenious Devices. Contains programmable automata - medieval robots and the ancestor of programmable machines.

texts.author: Banū Mūsā
texts.title: Kitāb al-Ḥiyal
texts.significance: Book of Ingenious Devices. Contains ~100 mechanical devices including automatic controls and feedback mechanisms.

texts.author: al-Fārābī
texts.title: Kitāb al-Mūsīqā al-Kabīr
texts.significance: Grand Book of Music. Mathematical music theory that influenced both Islamic and European traditions.

texts.author: al-Fārābī
texts.title: Sharḥ Kitāb al-'Ibāra
texts.significance: Commentary on Aristotle's De Interpretatione. Develops sophisticated modal logic and philosophy of language.

texts.author: Ibn Sīnā (Avicenna)
texts.title: al-Shifā' (Logic sections)
texts.significance: The Cure/Healing - encyclopedic work. Logic sections develop original modal logic. Partial translations exist.

texts.author: Ibn Sīnā (Avicenna)
texts.title: al-Ishārāt wa'l-Tanbīhāt
texts.significance: Pointers and Reminders. Mature philosophical system with sophisticated epistemology.

texts.author: Ibn Rushd (Averroes)
texts.title: Talkhīṣ Kitāb al-Burhān
texts.significance: Middle Commentary on Posterior Analytics. Essential for understanding demonstrative science.

texts.author: Ibn Rushd (Averroes)
texts.title: Tahāfut al-Tahāfut
texts.significance: The Incoherence of the Incoherence - defense of philosophy against al-Ghazālī. Central to medieval debate on reason vs revelation.
texts.existingTranslations: Van den Bergh (1954) - needs modern accessible edition

texts.author: al-Bīrūnī
texts.title: Kitāb al-Tafhīm
texts.significance: Book of Instruction in the Elements of Astral Science. Comprehensive mathematical astronomy.

texts.author: al-Bīrūnī
texts.title: al-Qānūn al-Mas'ūdī
texts.significance: Mas'ūdic Canon. Major astronomical work with sophisticated mathematical methods.

texts.author: al-Kindī
texts.title: Rasā'il al-Kindī al-Falsafiyya
texts.significance: Philosophical Epistles. First systematic Arabic philosophy - bridges Greek and Islamic thought.

texts.author: al-Ghazālī
texts.title: Mi'yār al-'Ilm
texts.significance: The Standard of Knowledge. Logic textbook that introduced logic to traditional Islamic scholars.

texts.author: al-Ghazālī
texts.title: Maqāṣid al-Falāsifa
texts.significance: Intentions of the Philosophers. Exposition of Avicennan philosophy before critique.

texts.author: Naṣīr al-Dīn al-Ṭūsī
texts.title: Taḥrīr Uṣūl Uqlīdis
texts.significance: Recension of Euclid's Elements. Critical edition with original contributions to geometry.

texts.author: Naṣīr al-Dīn al-Ṭūsī
texts.title: Tajrīd al-I'tiqād
texts.significance: Stripping of Belief. Systematic theology with philosophical sophistication. Major influence on later Islamic thought.

texts.author: Ibn al-Haytham (Alhazen)
texts.title: Kitāb al-Manāẓir (full)
texts.significance: Book of Optics. Established experimental method. Scientific revolution 600 years before Europe.
texts.existingTranslations: Sabra (Books I-III only); Books IV-VII untranslated

texts.author: al-Rāzī (Fakhr al-Dīn)
texts.title: al-Maṭālib al-'Āliya
texts.significance: The Higher Issues. Major synthesis of philosophy and theology. Sophisticated argumentation.

texts.author: al-Rāzī (Fakhr al-Dīn)
texts.title: al-Mulakhkhaṣ fī'l-Manṭiq
texts.significance: Summary of Logic. Influential post-Avicennan logic textbook.

texts.author: al-Kātibī
texts.title: al-Shamsiyya fī'l-Qawā'id al-Manṭiqiyya
texts.significance: The most widely used logic textbook in the Islamic world for 700 years. Taught in madrasas today.

persian.name: Persian & Safavid Philosophy
persian.description: The Isfahan School (16th-17th century) developed original philosophical systems synthesizing Peripatetic, Illuminationist, and mystical traditions. Most works remain untranslated.

texts.author: Mulla Sadra (Ṣadr al-Dīn al-Shīrāzī)
texts.title: al-Ḥikma al-Muta'āliya fī'l-Asfār al-'Aqliyya al-Arba'a
texts.significance: The Four Journeys - 9-volume magnum opus. Most important Islamic philosopher after Avicenna. Entirely untranslated to English.
texts.existingTranslations: Persian and Urdu only; no English

texts.author: Mulla Sadra
texts.title: al-Shawāhid al-Rubūbiyya
texts.significance: Divine Witnesses - concise presentation of his metaphysics including the primacy of existence.

texts.author: Mulla Sadra
texts.title: Mafātīḥ al-Ghayb
texts.significance: Keys to the Unseen - philosophical Qur'anic commentary. Sophisticated hermeneutics.

texts.author: Suhrawardī
texts.title: Ḥikmat al-Ishrāq
texts.significance: Philosophy of Illumination - founded ishraqi school. None of his works were translated into Latin; unknown in the West until Corbin.
texts.existingTranslations: Walbridge/Ziai (1999) - text only, needs accessible edition

texts.author: Suhrawardī
texts.title: al-Talwīḥāt
texts.significance: Intimations - one of four major Arabic philosophical works critiquing Peripatetic philosophy.

texts.author: Suhrawardī
texts.title: al-Muqāwamāt
texts.significance: Appositions - early work developing critique of Avicennan philosophy.

texts.author: Suhrawardī
texts.title: al-Mashāri' wa'l-Muṭāraḥāt
texts.significance: Paths and Havens - comprehensive philosophical treatise before Hikmat al-Ishraq.

texts.author: Mīr Dāmād
texts.title: al-Qabasāt
texts.significance: The Firebrand - teacher of Mulla Sadra. Original metaphysics of time (ḥudūth dahrī).

texts.author: Mīr Ghiyāth al-Dīn Manṣūr Dashtakī
texts.title: Philosophical Works
texts.significance: Major philosopher of Shiraz little known even to specialists. Mulla Sadra addressed his positions.

texts.author: Shams al-Dīn Muḥammad Khafrī
texts.title: Philosophical Works
texts.significance: Another major philosopher of Shiraz. Important for pre-Mulla Sadra developments.

tibetan.name: Tibetan Buddhist Logic & Epistemology
tibetan.description: The Tengyur contains 66 epistemological treatises. Most remain untranslated. The 84000 project aims to translate 70,000 pages of canonical texts.

texts.author: Dharmakīrti (Tibetan transmission)
texts.title: Pramāṇavārttika (Chapters II-IV)
texts.significance: Chapters on Perception, Inference for Others, and Inference for Oneself remain untranslated. Chapter I has Mookerjee trans.

texts.author: Devendrabuddhi
texts.title: Pramāṇavārttika-pañjikā
texts.significance: Earliest commentary on Dharmakīrti. Essential for interpretation.

texts.author: Śākyabuddhi
texts.title: Pramāṇavārttika-ṭīkā
texts.significance: Early Indian commentary on Dharmakīrti, preserved only in Tibetan.

texts.author: Karṇakagomin
texts.title: Pramāṇavārttika-svavṛtti-ṭīkā
texts.significance: Commentary on Dharmakīrti's auto-commentary. Important for understanding original intent.

texts.author: Manorathanandin
texts.title: Pramāṇavārttika-vṛtti
texts.significance: Late Indian commentary, influential in Tibet.

texts.author: Dignāga
texts.title: Pramāṇasamuccaya (Tibetan)
texts.significance: Foundational text of Buddhist epistemology. Sanskrit mostly lost, Tibetan translation essential.
texts.existingTranslations: Hayes (Ch. V); Hattori (Ch. I); much remains untranslated

texts.author: Śāntarakṣita
texts.title: Tattvasaṃgraha
texts.significance: Encyclopedic defense of Buddhist philosophy against all opponents.

texts.author: Kamalaśīla
texts.title: Tattvasaṃgraha-pañjikā
texts.significance: Commentary on Śāntarakṣita essential for understanding arguments.

texts.author: Phya pa Chos kyi seng ge
texts.title: Tshad ma yid kyi mun sel
texts.significance: Removing Mental Darkness - foundational Tibetan epistemological text. Original Tibetan philosophy.

texts.author: Sa skya Paṇḍita
texts.title: Tshad ma rigs pa'i gter
texts.significance: Treasury of Logic - most influential Tibetan epistemological treatise.

byzantine.name: Byzantine Greek Philosophy
byzantine.description: Byzantine commentaries on ancient Greek texts remain understudied and undervalued compared to Late-Antique, Medieval Latin, and Arabic traditions.

texts.author: George Pachymeres
texts.title: Philosophia (Aristotelian Compendium)
texts.significance: Voluminous paraphrase-compendium covering logic, natural philosophy, metaphysics and ethics.

texts.author: George Pachymeres
texts.title: Commentary on the Organon
texts.significance: Exegetical commentaries on Aristotle's logical works.

texts.author: George Pachymeres
texts.title: Commentary on Plato
texts.significance: The only Late Byzantine commentary on Plato.

texts.author: Johannes Italos
texts.title: Commentary on Topics
texts.significance: Important Byzantine commentary on Aristotle's Topics.

texts.author: Leon Magentinos
texts.title: Commentary on Prior Analytics
texts.significance: Byzantine commentary on Aristotle's syllogistic logic.

texts.author: Michael of Ephesus
texts.title: Commentary on Sophistical Refutations
texts.significance: Major Byzantine commentator on Aristotle. Analysis of fallacies.

texts.author: Georgios Gemistos Plethon
texts.title: Nomoi (Laws)
texts.significance: Late Byzantine Platonist who influenced the Italian Renaissance. Most of his works destroyed.

syriac.name: Syriac Philosophical Translations
syriac.description: Syriac-speaking Christians translated Greek philosophy into Syriac before Arabic. Many Greek works survive only in Syriac translation.

texts.author: Sergius of Reshaina
texts.title: Translations and Commentaries on Aristotle
texts.significance: First known exposition of Aristotle in a Semitic language. Translated Aristotle and Galen.

texts.author: Ḥunayn ibn Isḥāq
texts.title: Risāla (Letter on Translations)
texts.significance: Crucial source on Greek-Syriac-Arabic transmission. Lists translations and manuscripts.

texts.author: Bar Hebraeus (Gregory Abū'l-Faraj)
texts.title: Ḥewath Ḥekhmetha (Cream of Wisdom)
texts.significance: Encyclopedic work preserving Greek philosophical traditions. Contains quotations from lost works.

texts.author: Proba
texts.title: Commentary on Porphyry's Isagoge
texts.significance: Early Syriac logical commentary. Part of transmission to Islamic world.

texts.author: Anonymous
texts.title: Causa Causarum
texts.significance: Syriac encyclopedia of natural philosophy. Contains material not found elsewhere.

ethiopic.name: Ethiopian Ge'ez Philosophy
ethiopic.description: Ethiopia produced original philosophical texts in Ge'ez, including the remarkable 17th-century Hatata tradition of rational inquiry.

texts.author: Zara Yaqob
texts.title: Ḥatäta Zär'a Ya'ǝqob
texts.significance: The Inquiry - African Enlightenment philosophy emphasizing reason over religious dogma. Written in a cave during exile.

texts.author: Walda Heywat
texts.title: Ḥatäta Wäldä Ḥəywät
texts.significance: Student of Zara Yaqob. Develops ethical philosophy emphasizing reason and compassion.

texts.author: Various
texts.title: Mashafa Berhan (Book of Light)
texts.significance: Major Ethiopian theological work with philosophical arguments.

texts.author: Various
texts.title: Fetha Nagast (Law of the Kings)
texts.significance: Ethiopian legal code with philosophical foundations. Influenced by Byzantine and Coptic traditions.

latin.name: Medieval & Renaissance Latin
latin.description: Thousands of Latin texts from the Middle Ages and Renaissance remain untranslated, including original scientific and philosophical works.

texts.author: Ramón Llull
texts.title: Ars Magna (complete)
texts.significance: Combinatorial logic machine - Leibniz's direct inspiration. The first attempt at mechanical reasoning.
texts.existingTranslations: Bonner (selected works); complete Ars Magna unavailable

texts.author: John Buridan
texts.title: Summulae de Dialectica
texts.significance: Most influential medieval logic textbook. Contains original contributions to semantics and modality.

texts.author: William of Ockham
texts.title: Summa Logicae (complete)
texts.significance: Nominalist logic - razor principle in action. Revolutionary semantics.
texts.existingTranslations: Freddoso (Part II only); Parts I, III need translation

texts.author: Paul of Venice
texts.title: Logica Magna
texts.significance: Massive systematic logic treatise. Contains sophisticated modal logic.
texts.existingTranslations: Parts published by British Academy; much remains

texts.author: Walter Burley
texts.title: De Puritate Artis Logicae
texts.significance: On the Purity of the Art of Logic - important realist logic opposing Ockham.

greek.name: Greek Philosophy & Science
greek.description: Even ancient Greek texts have significant untranslated portions, especially commentaries and technical treatises.

texts.author: Alexander of Aphrodisias
texts.title: Commentary on Prior Analytics (Book II)
texts.significance: Most important ancient commentary on Aristotle's logic. Book II still untranslated.

texts.author: John Philoponus
texts.title: Commentary on Posterior Analytics
texts.significance: Revolutionary commentary criticizing Aristotelian physics. Proto-scientific method.

texts.author: Simplicius
texts.title: Commentary on Categories
texts.significance: Major late ancient commentary preserving lost Stoic and Peripatetic views.

texts.author: Ammonius Hermiae
texts.title: Commentary on De Interpretatione
texts.significance: Important for understanding ancient debates on future contingents.

hebrew.name: Hebrew Philosophy & Kabbalah
hebrew.description: Medieval Jewish philosophy and mysticism contains sophisticated logical and metaphysical analysis.

texts.author: Gersonides (Levi ben Gershon)
texts.title: Sefer Milḥamot Hashem (Wars of the Lord)
texts.significance: Original philosophical system with sophisticated logic and natural philosophy.

texts.author: Gersonides
texts.title: Supercommentary on Averroes' Logic
texts.significance: Commentary on Averroes' commentaries on Aristotle's logic. Important for transmission history.

texts.author: Abraham ibn Daud
texts.title: Ha-Emunah ha-Ramah (The Exalted Faith)
texts.significance: First systematic Aristotelian Jewish philosophy. Influenced Maimonides.
texts.existingTranslations: Partial translations exist; needs complete edition

texts.author: Joseph Albo
texts.title: Sefer ha-Ikkarim (Book of Principles)
texts.significance: Systematic Jewish theology with philosophical foundations.

chinese.name: Chinese Logic & Philosophy
chinese.description: The School of Names (Míngjiā) and later Buddhist logic in China developed sophisticated argumentation.

texts.author: Gongsun Long
texts.title: Gongsun Longzi (complete)
texts.significance: 'White Horse Not Horse' paradox. Sophisticated semantics and ontology.
texts.existingTranslations: Graham, Harbsmeier - fragments; no complete scholarly translation

texts.author: Later Mohists
texts.title: Mohist Canon (Mo Jing)
texts.significance: Systematic logic, epistemology, and physics. Parallel developments to Greek logic.
texts.existingTranslations: Graham (1978) - but needs updating with new scholarship

texts.author: Xuanzang
texts.title: Cheng weishi lun (Vijñaptimātratāsiddhi)
texts.significance: Synthesis of Indian Yogācāra philosophy. Foundation of East Asian Buddhist philosophy.

texts.author: Kuiji
texts.title: Cheng weishi lun shuji
texts.significance: Major commentary on Xuanzang's work. Essential for interpretation.

japanese.name: Japanese Buddhist Philosophy
japanese.description: Major Japanese Buddhist thinkers like Kūkai and Dōgen developed sophisticated philosophical systems largely untranslated.

texts.author: Kūkai
texts.title: Jūjūshinron (Ten Stages of Mind)
texts.significance: 10-volume magnum opus positioning esoteric Buddhism as culmination of all religious thought.

texts.author: Kūkai
texts.title: Hizō hōyaku (Precious Key to the Secret Treasury)
texts.significance: Abridged version of Jūjūshinron, more accessible.

texts.author: Dōgen
texts.title: Shōbōgenzō (Treasury of the True Dharma Eye)
texts.significance: Philosophical masterwork on Buddha-nature and time. Major Buddhist philosopher.
texts.existingTranslations: Nishijima/Cross (complete but criticized); needs scholarly edition

texts.author: Saichō
texts.title: Tendai Works
texts.significance: Founder of Japanese Tendai. Philosophical foundations for later Japanese Buddhism.
texts.existingTranslations: Paul Groner (historical studies); texts largely untranslated
